content.description: Nice, varnished wide hands and fist crack. Somewhat of a right facing corner. A little steep at the start, and gets a little wide at the top.
content.protection: BD: 3-4. I think you could place a 5 near the top, but I don't really remember.
content.location: Starts off a big ledge just right of where the approach trail hits the wall. You can see this route and the chains from the hike up. Even bigger ledge on the top.

content.description:
Yeah, it's short, but it's pretty sweet. Makes for a friendly and accessible first Creek lead, or an unintimidating way to practice what are generally considered "bad sizes". Lucky for Ilana, she gets thin hands in baggy .5's, but the rest of us will be left wondering when the last time we finger stacked on a 5.9 was.

Lots of face holds, less than vertical, and definitely not the shortest route in the Creek (ever been to Pistol Whipped?).
content.location: It's right in the middle of the wall, just right of a big right-facing OW corner. Look for the chains in a rock scar 30' up.

content.description:
Fun, fairly friendly offwidth. Good for practicing the dreaded #6's - at least I dread them.

Start up a section of #3's and #4's in a flare to gain a ledge. Get psyched, then launch into steep 5's and 6's to the chains out left.
content.protection: BD: 3 - 6. One of each in that size range if you're really comfy on OW's of the grade, but I think most would find a second 6 (or even better, an old green #5) to be pretty nice.
content.location: Center-right on the wall. Plaque at base. Lots of choss to the left.

content.description:
One of the classics of the wall. Crisp tight hands and finger stacks in a right facing corner.

It's located in a fairly recent rock scar, on some aesthetic pink Wingate. Great friction and good feet.
content.protection: BD: .5 to 1. Bring a lot of greens and reds (3-5 ea? I don't quite remember), with a couple purps for the top.
content.location: Currently the rightmost route on the wall, just left of the major arch in the big rock scar. Talus field at the base.

content.description:
A beautiful, varnished left facing dihedral. "Not your typical Creek route" - a description which seems to be becoming more and more typical.

The corner begins easy enough, with good stances and occasional finger pods, but progressively ramps up in difficulty before the final crescendo of burning calves, tiny gear, and trusting the rubber.

Unless you have tiny, tiny fingers, expect to climb this route with your legs more than your hands. The inside of the crack is varnished, making the small gear feel very solid. You can place cams every inch of the way, but you'll likely commit to sequences above your gear at some point.
content.protection:
A variety of cams in the purple and blue metolius range - having a mix of brands is helpful. I placed 4 blue metolius, 2 red c3's, 3 purple metolius and a gray metolius. You might want more if onsighting at your limit or nesting gear or aiding, but I felt like I sewed it up pretty good.

Black totems and yellow dragonfly's protect nicely where the crack pinches between purple and blue. BD .3's are too big. There are a couple finger pods down low where you can place a "big cam" in the .3-.5 range, but you'll also want your fingers there.
content.location: Directly above where the trail meets the wall. Starts off a small ledge.
